title: Ready, player one: the $75bn deal launching Microsoft into the metaverse
text:
One thing to start: The two big US competition agencies are to overhaul merger guidelines, which could make it far harder to conclude large deals as the Biden administration seeks to crack down on anti-competitive practices.

And in case you missed it: DD's James Fontanella-Khan spoke with Gregg Lemkau, the Goldman Sachs veteran who quit to run Michael Dell's family office MSD Partners. Watch our inaugural DD: Dialogues event on-demand here.

Microsoft levels up with the world's largest tech deal

We knew Satya Nadella was looking for a monster deal.

At first, it seemed like the chair and chief executive of Microsoft was more interested in social media.

Back in 2020, Nadella made a move to buy the viral video app group TikTok, but that fell through. Then last year he tried scooping up Pinterest to no avail. Undeterred, he tried to bag chat start-up Discord but got rebuffed.

Ultimately, the Hyderabad-born executive settled on voice recognition pioneer Nuance Communications for $16bn, a deal that few found inspiring. Smart observers at the time told DD that Nadella wasn't finished yet.

He didn't disappoint. On Tuesday Microsoft pulled out the big guns, agreeing to buy video game maker Activision Blizzard for an equity value of $75bn — the largest gaming deal in history by far.

DD can only imagine that part of the thought process for the deal was: why go small when you're sitting on a $130bn cash pile? The reality is obviously a little more complex and detailed.

Over the years, the company co-founded in 1975 by Bill Gates and Paul Allen has been transformed from a software-focused company to a diversified tech conglomerate ranging from cloud computing to social media and obviously gaming.

Much of that diversification has occurred through big acquisitions including the 2011 takeover of Skype for $8.5bn, and the $26bn purchase of LinkedIn five years later.

Gaming isn't new to Microsoft. At the turn of the century, it launched the gaming console Xbox to compete with Nintendo and Sony. But the industry has moved online, with subscription plans and original content at the forefront as players hunt for deals to propel them into the metaverse, aka the immersive virtual worlds that the big tech companies are racing to build.

Microsoft began to catch on, acquiring ZeniMax, the gaming group behind major franchises such as Fallout and Doom, for $7.5bn. 

Activision, with its rich content portfolio of brands like Call of Duty and World of Warcraft, will help the tech giant gain a further edge on rivals including Take-Two Interactive, the maker of the popular Grand Theft Auto game series that agreed to buy rival Zynga for $12.7bn last week.  

The deal wouldn't only push Microsoft ahead in gaming, but help it carve out a sizeable plot in the metaverse land grab, Lex notes.

It all seems pretty logical, in the grand scheme of things. But one obstacle Nadella could be underestimating is antitrust.

After US president Joe Biden appointed Big Tech adversaries Lina Khan and Tim Wu to senior positions within his administration, it was assumed that Microsoft and its competitors at Google, Amazon and Facebook would steer clear of large-scale M&A.

Microsoft's play for Activision will test whether the current administration can successfully square off against Big Tech, and win.

The endless mess at Credit Suisse

In the 2021 Wimbledon men's singles final, vaccine sceptic Novak Djokovic claimed the trophy over Matteo Berrettini in the fourth set when his opponent missed a final backhand slice.

António Horta-Osório, the now-former Credit Suisse chair who watched from the sidelines in London despite the 10-day quarantine rule imposed on Swiss travellers at the time, suffered a similar defeat thanks to his own unforced errors.

After vowing to turn round the scandal-hit lender in the aftermath of twin crises at Archegos and Greensill, the Portuguese banker was informed this week that the Credit Suisse board, which he had chaired for just over eight months, no longer supported him after repeated Covid-19 quarantine breaches.

It's the second high-profile departure of a top leader at the bank in two years, following Tidjane Thiam's ousting as CEO in the wake of a corporate espionage scandal in 2020.

Horta-Osório ultimately resigned, a person close to him told the FT, when he learnt this past Sunday afternoon that less than half of the directors indicated they would be willing to back him in light of his indiscretions. They included the tennis excursion and a trip to a luxury resort in the Maldives on the company's corporate jet.

Axel Lehmann, the Credit Suisse board member and former UBS executive who has been drafted in as his replacement, inherits a bank and boardroom in disarray. Horta-Osório had orchestrated a power grab just months after joining as chair, sowing tensions with CEO Thomas Gottstein as he expanded his own office and took a direct role in decision making.

With his position safe for now, Gottstein may get a second shot at the “clean slate” he had bargained for last year. That's if he can finally sweep over the extensive laundry list of scandals the bank has endured over the past decade.

As for Horta-Osório, he'll get a SFr3.8m ($4.1m) leaving package — three-quarters of what he would have been entitled to annually — to tide him over until he makes his next move.

Lehmann and Gottstein's first order of business, if you ask DD?

Finishing what Horta-Osório started when he vowed to overhaul the bank's pay policy. The last thing they want is for its risk managers and attorneys to stray elsewhere.

David Solomon's 2022 forecast: ‘wage inflation everywhere'

Goldman Sachs bankers rang in the new year with huge bonuses following a record-breaking year for dealmaking. But lacklustre earnings quickly sullied the mood on Tuesday, as the bank's stock plunged by 7 per cent.

“There's no question that inflationary pressures around compensation had an impact,” said the bank's CEO David Solomon in an interview with the FT's Josh Franklin, warning of “wage inflation everywhere”.

Net profit fell 13 per cent year-on-year in the last three months of 2021 — a drop surpassing analysts' expectations. Meanwhile, bonuses were up 31 per cent on the year, more than the $2.9bn analysts had originally predicted, while annual salary expenses were up 22 per cent.

It's hardly a surprise the Wall Street bank spent vast sums on its employees in the fourth quarter, as a reckoning over junior pay and discourse surrounding mental health issues put Goldman's much-touted “pay for performance” culture to the test.

Also fuelling the drop in Goldman's stock on Tuesday was an underwhelming performance by the bank's trading division. After a banner 2020 thanks to heavy trading during the pandemic, revenue was down 7 per cent at $3.98bn year-on-year. That's below analysts' forecasts of $4.3bn.

Solomon has put on a brave face nonetheless. “If you're a student of the history of Goldman Sachs,” he said, “every time the firm has an extraordinary year, people say it will never be better . . . and there's always a time when it's better.”

Job moves

  • Law firm Paul Weiss has hired Kenneth Ziman as a partner in its restructuring practice, based in New York. He was previously a managing director at Lazard.

  • Teneo has appointed Jay Goffman as client chair of its financial advisory business. He was previously vice-chair of global advisory at Rothschild & Co. The CEO advisory firm also hired former New York Times business journalist Nelson Schwartz as a managing director.

  • Law firm Eversheds Sutherland has hired Christopher Williams as a partner in its City-based banking practice. He joins from Linklaters.
